questions.text: The hormone leptin is derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Leptin is an adipocyte-derived hormone.

It acts through brain circuits (predominantly in the hypothalamus) to influence appetite, energy expenditure, and neuroendocrine function. High leptin levels reduce appetite and increase energy expenditure.

The arcuate nucleus in the hypothalamus plays an important role in the regulation of appetite.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman has been fasting all day as part of a new diet. Which of the following is a gut peptide that will be increased in this woman?
questions.solution:
In the fasting state, high levels of ghrelin are seen. It is a gut-peptide produced in the stomach and stimulates hunger and appetite.

Related Pearl: Neurotransmitters and Hormones that influence Feeding and Satiety Centers in the Hypothalamus

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy ate two pieces of cake, a sandwich, and two scoops of ice cream at his friend's birthday party an hour ago. Levels of which of the following are likely to be high in this boy?
questions.solution:
This boy is likely to have high levels of α-Melanocyte-stimulating hormone (α-MSH). It is a hypothalamic peptide that decreases appetite and hence would be increased in the fed state.

questions.text: Which of the following is a key transcription factor involved in the differentiation of mesenchymal preadipocytes to adipose cells?
questions.solution:
One of the key transcription factors involved in the differentiation of mesenchymal preadipocytes to adipose cells is the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ). It is a nuclear receptor that also binds the thiazolidinedione class of insulin-sensitizing drugs used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Note: Saroglitazar has a dual action on PPARα and PPARùù≤ receptors. It reduces blood sugar and lipid levels in diabetic patients.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding adiponectin?

choices.text: Its levels are increased in obesity

questions.solution:
Adiponectin levels are reduced in obesity.

It is an abundant adipose-derived protein with the following characteristics: 

  • Its levels are reduced in obesity
  • It enhances insulin sensitivity and lipid oxidation
  • Has vascular-protective effects

On the other hand, resistin and RBP4 levels, which are also secreted by adipocytes, may induce insulin resistance.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl is referred to an endocrinologist with severe obesity and insatiable hunger despite adequate nutrition. Due to the early-onset severe obesity, genetic testing was done and revealed inactivating mutations in the leptin gene. Which of the following neuroendocrine abnormalities is this child most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
The most prominent neuroendocrine abnormality seen in obese individuals with inactivating mutations in the leptin (ob gene) or leptin receptor (db gene) is hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Leptin mutations are responsible for a rare form of obesity that runs in families. These mutations prevent leptin from delivering satiety signals. Hence, the brain perceives starvation despite adequate nutrition. It results in morbid, early-onset obesity.

Mutations in the following genes can cause obesity in humans:

  • Lep (ob)
  • LepR (db)
  • POMC
  • PC-1
  • MC4R

questions.text: Genetic mutations causing pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC) deficiency presents with all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Cachexia is not a feature of mutations of the pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC) gene. It is associated with the following characteristics:

  • Absence of α-MSH
    • Severe obesity - α-MSH inhibits appetite in the hypothalamus
    • Pale skin and red hair 
  • Absence of ACTH
    • Secondary adrenal insufficiency

questions.text: The production of which of the following hormones is increased in obesity?
questions.solution:
Insulin levels are increased in obesity. It stimulates the synthesis of fatty acids and TAG and decreases the rate of lipolysis. Thyroxine, growth hormone, and adiponectin have lipolytic effects, hence their levels are reduced in obesity.

Hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance are consistent features of obesity. Insulin resistance is more strongly linked to intra-abdominal fat than to fat in other areas.

Adiponectin (Option D) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine that is produced by adipocytes. It performs vital functions that are reduced in obesity - like, increasing insulin sensitivity and the inhibition of gluconeogenic enzymes. It also enhances fatty acid oxidation.

Insulin resistance in obesity occurs as a result of the following:

  • Insulin receptor downregulation
  • Increased FFA (free fatty acids) and capable of impairing insulin action
  • Intracellular lipid accumulation
  • Circulating peptides produced by adipocytes such as TNF-α, IL-6, RBP4, and resistin modify insulin action.

questions.text: In a child with obesity, hypogonadism, and mental retardation, which of the following would you not suspect ?
questions.solution:
Children with Angelman syndrome present with mental retardation but do not have obesity and hypogonadism. It occurs due to the deletion of band q12 of the maternal chromosome 15.

The following syndromes present with obesity, hypogonadism, and mental retardation

  • Prader-Willi syndrome - deletion of band q12 of the paternal chromosome 15.
  • Laurence-Moon-Bardet-Biedl syndrome
  • Carpenter syndrome
  • Cohen syndrome

The following image shows a child with Prader-Willi syndrome.

questions.text: Obesity is not seen in patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Sipple syndrome is characterized by pheochromocytoma which is associated with weight loss.

Obesity is seen in the following syndromes:

  • Cushing's syndrome
  • Prader-Willi syndrome
  • Pickwickian syndrome
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Insulinoma
  • Craniopharyngioma and other hypothalamic disorders
  • Laurence-Moon-Bardet-Biedl syndrome
  • Carpenter syndrome
  • Cohen syndrome

According to the WHO classification, a BMI of 34¬†kg/m¬≤ would be classified as class I obesity.

The revised BMI classification for Asians/Indians is as follows:

  • Underweight - BMI < 18.5 kg/m2¬†

Note: As the question does not specify Asian/Indian, the answer is given according to WHO classification.

A recent study shows that people with a body mass index(BMI) more than or equal to 35 is associated with a higher risk of death in patients with COVID-19.

questions.text: A known patient of type 2 diabetes mellitus on oral medication presents to your OPD for review. His blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg and his BMI is 28.4 kg/m¬≤. His fasting glucose is 118 mg/dl and postprandial glucose is 154 mg/dl. He consumes a low-calorie diet and exercises regularly. How will you manage his obesity?

choices.text: Start him on a more intense diet and exercise regimen
Anti-obesity drugs in combination with proper diet and exercise
Anti-obesity drugs alone as lifestyle changes have not been effective

questions.solution:
This obese man with a BMI of 28.4 kg/m² along with comorbidities must be managed with anti-obesity drugs as an adjunct to comprehensive lifestyle modifications.

The recommendations for management of obesity are as follows:

  • Diet, exercise, behavioral therapy: 
    • BMI - 25-29.9 with comorbidities
    • BMI ≥ 30
  • Adjunctive pharmacotherapy:
    • BMI - 27-29.9 with comorbidities
    • BMI ≥ 30
  • Bariatric surgery:
    • BMI - 35-39.9 with comorbidities
    • BMI ≥ 40

questions.text: Which of the following anti-obesity drugs is a selective 5-HT2C receptor agonist?
questions.solution:
Lorcaserin is a selective 5-HT2C receptor agonist with a functional selectivity ~15 times that of 5-HT2A receptors and 100 times that of 5-HT2B  receptors.

Based on a safety clinical trial, the FDA has announced, withdrawal of the drug lorcarserin on Feb 13th 2020, as the potential risk of cancer outweighs the benefits.

Related Pearl: Anti-obesity drugs

Centrally acting anti-obesity drugs: The biologic effect of these agents on appetite regulation is produced by augmentation of the neurotransmission of three monoamines,¬†norepinephrine, serotonin (5-HT) and¬†dopamine.

  • Phentermine ‚Äì Sympathomimetic (Phentermine is usually used in combination with topiramate)
  • Lorcaserin ‚Äì Selective 5-HT2C receptor agonist

Peripherally acting medications:

  • Orlistat is a synthetic hydrogenated derivative of a naturally occurring lipase inhibitor, lipostatin, that is produced by the mold Streptomyces toxytricini.

Anti-obesity drugs in development:

  • Bupropion:¬†Dopamine and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor
  • Naltrexone:¬†Opioid receptor antagonist

Liraglutide:¬†Glucagon-like peptide 1 receptor agonist

Note: Tirzepatide is a GIP and GLP-1 agonist recently approved for weight loss treatment.
